reviews.author: DataScientist42
reviews.use_case: Creating publication-ready figures for academic papers in ecology
reviews.hardest_part: Understanding the difference between aes() inside vs outside geom layers
reviews.best_thing: The grammar of graphics approach - once you understand it, you can build almost any visualization
reviews.would_improve: Better error messages when aesthetic mappings are wrong
reviews.tips: Start with the R for Data Science book chapter on ggplot2. Learn aes() and the layer system first.

reviews.author: RUser2024
reviews.use_case: Daily data cleaning and transformation for survey data
reviews.hardest_part: Understanding when to use group_by vs rowwise
reviews.best_thing: The pipe syntax and verb-based approach completely changed how I work with data
reviews.would_improve: The transition from older versions sometimes breaks code
reviews.tips: Learn the core verbs first: filter, select, mutate, summarize, arrange. Then add group_by.

reviews.author: EpiModeler
reviews.use_case: Real-time Rt estimation during COVID-19 outbreak response
reviews.hardest_part: Setting up appropriate priors for the delay distributions
reviews.missing_feature: Better support for multiple data streams
reviews.best_thing: State-of-the-art Rt estimation with proper uncertainty quantification
reviews.would_improve: More beginner-friendly vignettes with real-world examples
reviews.tips: Start with the simple examples and use default priors initially. Join the community Slack for help.

reviews.author: AppBuilder
reviews.use_case: Building internal dashboards for stakeholders to explore data
reviews.hardest_part: Understanding reactive programming and when to use reactive() vs observe()
reviews.best_thing: Building interactive web apps without knowing web development
reviews.would_improve: Debugging reactive chains can be frustrating
reviews.tips: Use reactlog to visualize your reactive graph. Start simple and add complexity gradually.

reviews.author: PublicHealthPro
reviews.use_case: Building epidemic curves for respiratory illness surveillance
reviews.hardest_part: Nothing major - the API is intuitive
reviews.best_thing: The grouping functionality for stratified analysis is excellent
reviews.tips: Check out the epiverse-trace tutorials for worked examples with real outbreak data.

reviews.author: BayesianBob
reviews.use_case: Multilevel regression models for psychology research
reviews.hardest_part: Choosing appropriate priors and understanding Stan diagnostics
reviews.best_thing: The formula interface makes specifying complex hierarchical models easy
reviews.would_improve: Compilation time can be slow for complex models
reviews.tips: Learn basic Bayesian concepts first. Use default priors to start, then refine based on prior predictive checks.

reviews.author: GeoAnalyst
reviews.use_case: Mapping disease incidence data at administrative boundaries
reviews.best_thing: Seamless integration with dplyr and ggplot2
reviews.would_improve: Some operations could be faster on large datasets
reviews.tips: If coming from sp, the switch is worth it. Read the sf vignettes carefully.

reviews.author: BigDataR
reviews.hardest_part: The [i, j, by] syntax is terse and takes time to internalize
reviews.best_thing: Speed - operations that took minutes with dplyr take seconds
reviews.would_improve: Syntax is less readable than dplyr for newcomers
reviews.tips: Learn the := operator early. Use .SD and .SDcols for column operations. Worth the learning investment for big data.

reviews.author: PackageDev
reviews.use_case: Unit testing for R packages in CI/CD pipeline
reviews.hardest_part: Mocking external dependencies like API calls
reviews.best_thing: The expect_* functions are intuitive and the test output is clear
reviews.would_improve: snapshot testing could have better diff display
reviews.tips: Start testing early in development. Use test_that() blocks to group related tests logically.

reviews.author: EpiFieldworker
reviews.use_case: Cleaning messy outbreak linelist data from field investigations
reviews.hardest_part: Understanding how tags work with different column types
reviews.best_thing: Standardization functions save hours of manual data cleaning
reviews.would_improve: More built-in validation rules for common epidemiological data issues
reviews.tips: Set up your linelist tags early - it makes downstream analysis much smoother.

reviews.author: MapMaker
reviews.use_case: Interactive disease maps in Shiny dashboards
reviews.best_thing: Creating interactive maps with just a few lines of code
reviews.tips: Use addProviderTiles() to try different basemap styles. Combine with sf for easy spatial data handling.

reviews.author: OutbreakResponse
reviews.use_case: Real-time severity assessment during outbreak response
reviews.hardest_part: Choosing the right delay distribution for adjustment
reviews.missing_feature: Confidence intervals could be wider to reflect true uncertainty
reviews.best_thing: The delay-adjusted CFR method is properly implemented
reviews.would_improve: More guidance on interpreting results during early outbreak phases
reviews.tips: Always use delay-adjusted estimates during ongoing outbreaks. The naive CFR is almost always biased.

reviews.author: BusinessAnalyst
reviews.use_case: Sales forecasting for quarterly business planning
reviews.hardest_part: Choosing between different model types (ARIMA vs ETS)
reviews.best_thing: auto.arima() is incredibly helpful for quick, reliable forecasting
reviews.would_improve: More guidance on when to use which model
reviews.tips: Start with auto.arima() for a baseline. Use accuracy() on holdout data to compare models.

reviews.author: ReportWriter
reviews.use_case: Automated weekly analysis reports for management
reviews.best_thing: Combining code, results, and narrative in one reproducible document
reviews.would_improve: Word output formatting could be more flexible
reviews.tips: Use parameterized reports for recurring analyses. Consider Quarto for newer projects.

reviews.author: TransmissionModeler
reviews.use_case: Finding delay distributions for epidemic model parameterization
reviews.best_thing: Having a standardized, citable database of epidemiological parameters
reviews.tips: Check the vignettes for worked examples of extracting parameters for specific diseases.

reviews.author: geepack
reviews.hardest_part:
I don't like zombie packages in R üßü‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è The geepack is such package, incredibly popular, though. Serious issues not fixed since 2021 (and no better in the past). Can crash your session under unstructured covariance and "waves" specified (used with missing observations). How many times have I cursed it! Plus the ordinal regression part returns nonsensical estimates (indicated by me and others).

Never again in my work. Replaced it entirely with a gem: glmtoolbox + multgee.
reviews.tips: Replace it with glmtoolbox (and multgee or repolr for ordinal regression).

reviews.author: glmtoolbox
reviews.tips:
‚úîÔ∏è author reacts relatively quickly and fixed the issues

‚úîÔ∏è capabilities beat those of geepack totally. To name a few:

üëâ families: gaussian, binomial, poisson, gamma, inverse gaussian, negative binomial, tweedie
üëâ stationary and non-stationary M-dependent and AR-M-dependent residual covariance structures
üëâ correct weighting for MAR (WGEE) - observation and cluster/subject-specific weights
üëâ Mancl-DeRouen bias-corrected sandwich for small sample inference! Also: standard sandwich, jacknife, df-adjusted, naive model-based
üëâ Model selection criteria like QIC, CIC, RJ, SGPC, GHYC, PAC, AGPC (yes! Akaike-type penalized Gaussian pseudo-likelihood)
üëâ Global and local influence diagnostics; Cook's distance, DFBETA, leverage 
üëâ Comparing nested models - stepwise selection (I never recommend it but if you want it - it is there), based on: QIC, QICU, AGPC, SGPC, Wald's and Score p-values
üëâ Pearson, Deviance and Mahalanobis residuals 
üëâ nonlinear predictors (gnmgee)!

‚úîÔ∏è doesn't crash! warns about unstable estimates (unlike geepack) 

‚úîÔ∏è lots of stuff for the GLM family!

‚úîÔ∏è talks with these packages - essential for clinical trials!
- broom
- mice
- emmeans
- marginaleffects
- easystat::insight
- easystat::parameters
- ggeffects

reviews.author: nfidd
reviews.best_thing: I really like how it builds up models element by element.
reviews.would_improve: It could do with a logo and using a Julia backend
reviews.tips: It is really designed for teaching material vs being used actively in other settings. That being said several projects have adapted code for research projects
